I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 

1. 
to Nepal for the additional financing of the Melamchi Water Supply Project (MWSP).1 
 
2. 
The MWSP supports infrastructure and institutional reforms that are critical to improving 
the Kathmandu Valley’s water supply. The Melamchi tunnel, a key component of the MWSP, is 
critical  for  supplying  bulk  water  to  the  Kathmandu  Valley,  and  its  performance  affects  the 
progress of several other downstream water supply and wastewater projects in the valley. The 
additional financing, which is needed to meet cost overruns resulting from the higher amount of 
the new contract for the Melamchi tunnel, is important to achieve the expected outcomes of the 
MWSP. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  Board  of  Directors  approved  the  MWSP  on  21 
December  2000,  and  the  project  became  effective  on  28  November  2001. 2  It  is  a 
comprehensive  water  supply  project  to  improve  the  health  and  wellbeing  of  the  people  in  the 
Kathmandu  Valley.  It  aims  to  alleviate  the  shortage  of  potable  water  in  the  valley  by  diverting 
water from the Melamchi River to the Kathmandu Valley.  

 

4. 
Since  2004,  major  events  and  changing  circumstances  in  Nepal  have  hampered  the 
implementation of the MWSP. The government’s efforts to secure private sector participation to 
manage water services in the Kathmandu Valley were  unsuccessful. During the initial years of 
the  MWSP,  private  sector  bidders  were  not  interested  in  a  lease  contract,  supported  by  the 
World  Bank, for  water services delivery. When  this  led  to  significant  delays  in  project  start-up, 
the  World  Bank  canceled  its  funding.  A  subsequent  ADB-supported  performance-based 
management  contract  also  failed  to  attract  private  sector  interest  despite  several  years  of 
focused  efforts.  The  government  and  ADB  realized  that  private  sector  engagement  in  Nepal’s 
urban water sector was too difficult in the unpredictable sociopolitical environment of that time. 
Consequently,  the  biggest  civil  works  package  under  the  MWSP—the  27.5  kilometer  (km) 
Melamchi  tunnel—was  put  on  hold  because  the  loan  covenants  included  a  condition  that  the 
performance-based  management  contract  had  to  be  awarded  before  the  contract  for  the 
Melamchi tunnel. Furthermore, three development partners withdrew from the MWSP because 
of political developments in that period,3 leaving a funding gap of $133 million equivalent. 
 
5. 
The  MWSP  experienced  additional  challenges.  ADB’s  Office  of  the  Special  Project 
Facilitator,  and  later  the  Compliance  Review  Panel,  initiated  investigations  in  May  2004  into  a

6. 
In 2008, ADB approved a major change in the scope and implementation arrangements 
of  the  loan  and  associated  projects  to  restructure  the  project  design,  optimize  the  available 
funding,  and  suit  the  changed  institutional  environment.5 The  most  important  change  was  the 
removal  of  the  loan  covenant  requiring  a  performance-based  management  contract  as  a 
condition  for  awarding  the  contract  for  the  Melamchi  tunnel.  The  restructuring  of  the  projects 
allowed  construction  of  the  tunnel,  which  had  been  on  hold  from  2000  to  2008,  to  begin.  The 
change  in  scope  did  not  alter  the  MWSP’s  development  benefits  or  impact.  Moreover,  the 
MWSP was divided into two subprojects with different implementing agencies, which enhanced 
implementation  efficiency  by  distributing  responsibilities.  The  Melamchi  Water  Supply 
Development  Board  (MWSDB)  continued  to  implement  the  Melamchi  River  water  diversion 
subproject  (subproject  1),  which  includes  the  Melamchi  tunnel.  The  newly  established  water 
utility  Kathmandu  Upatyaka  Khanepani  Limited  (KUKL)  became  the  implementing  agency  for 
the  Kathmandu  Valley  water  supply  and  sanitation  subproject  (subproject  2),  which  includes 
distribution network improvements in the valley.  
 
7. 
Following  the  restructuring  of  the  MWSP,  the  MWSDB  awarded  the  contract  for  the 
Melamchi  tunnel  to  China  Railway  15  Bureau  Group  Corporation  on  19  February  2009  for 
NRs4,288  million.  The  tunnel  was  scheduled  for  completion  by  2  September  2013.  Physical 
works  started  in  April  2010  because  of  the  time  required  for  preparations,  including  handing 
over  the  sites  to  the  contractor  and  addressing  social  problems  encountered  in  contract 
implementation.  The  MWSDB  terminated  the  contract  on  25  September  2012  because  of  the 
unsatisfactory  performance  of  the  contractor.  As  of  the  termination  date,  only  23%  of  tunnel 
excavation—6.3 km of 27.5 km—had been completed.   
 
8. 
The  MWSDB  rebid  the  tunnel  contract,  which  was  awarded  to  Cooperativa  Muratori  e 
Cementisti  di  Ravenna  of  Italy  on  15  July  2013  for  NRs8,727  million.  The  new  contract  is 
scheduled for completion on 30 September 2016. Additional financing of $25 million from ADB’s 
Special  Funds  resources,  which  is  proposed  to  meet  this  cost  overrun,  will  support  the 
completion of the Melamchi tunnel and the achievement of the original project’s outcomes. The 
proposed additional financing will not change the scope of the restructured project. 
 
9. 
While the  MWSP  is  not performing  well,  both the original  and the restructured projects 
remain  the  most  critical  components  of  the  water  supply  system  in  the  Kathmandu  Valley.  As 
the  Melamchi  tunnel  is  essential  to  achieving  the  full  benefits  of  an  improved  water  supply

 system in the Kathmandu Valley, a reduction in scope or cancellation of the project would not be 
appropriate. A reduction or cancellation of the project at this stage (i) would result in a waste of 
project  expenditures,  (ii)  would  be  detrimental  to  the  achievement  of  the  government’s  sector 
priorities,  and  (iii)  could  cause  potential  reputational  risk  for  ADB.  The  project  continues  to  be 
technically  feasible  and  economically  sound,  and  the  net  benefits  of  providing  additional 
financing to complete the project far outweigh any other option. 
 
10. 
Despite  the  difficulties,  the  government  has  consistently  maintained  its  commitment  to 
the  MWSP.  In  addition  to  continuing  infrastructure  development  under  the  MWSP,  the 
government  has  slowly  initiated  institutional  reforms.  The  most  important  reforms  include 
separation of asset ownership from management; establishment of an independent commission 
for regulating water tariffs; and establishment of an autonomous water operator company under 
the Companies Act (1996). Three key entities have been established: (i) the Kathmandu Valley 
Water  Supply  Management  Board,  asset  owner  of  water  and  wastewater  systems  within  the 
valley; (ii) the Water Supply Tariff Fixation Commission,  which is responsible for the economic 
regulation  of  the  sector;  and  (iii)  the  KUKL,  which  is  in  charge  of  operating  the  assets  under 
lease and license from Kathmandu Valley Water Supply Management Board. Laws have been 
amended or  enacted to allow  the  implementation  of these institutional reforms  and  the  private 
sector participation scheme.6 This level of institutional reform in the urban water sector has few 
parallels  in  South  Asia.  Moreover,  the  government  and  ADB  are  implementing  downstream 
improvement  in  the  water supply  distribution  network  and  wastewater  management  projects  in 
the Kathmandu Valley to improve the delivery of water supply and wastewater services.7 
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

11. 
The aggregate impact and outcome of the project as a result of the additional financing 
remain  the  same  as  those  of  the  current  project.  The  impact  will  be  the  improved  health  and 
well-being  of  the  people  of  the  Kathmandu  Valley.  The  outcome  will  be  the  alleviation  of  the 
shortage  of  potable water  in the  valley.  The  performance  targets  and  indicators for the  impact 
have  been  revised  to  reflect  the  sector-specific  impact  and  are  in  the  design  and  monitoring 
framework (Appendix 1).  
 
C. 

Outputs 

12. 
The additional financing will be provided for the Melamchi Valley Subproject (subproject 
1). The aggregate outputs of the MWSP’s two subprojects as a result of the additional financing 
will  broadly  remain  the  same  as  those  of  the  current  project.  The  minor  corrections,  mainly 
editorial, are in the design and monitoring framework.  
 
13. 
 

The subproject 1 outputs will be as follows: 

(i) 

Output  1:  Raw  water  diverted  from  Melamchi  Valley  to  Kathmandu  Valley. 
This output will include (a)  a 27.5 km Melamchi  diversion tunnel completed and 
170 million liters per day (MLD) of bulk water provided to Kathmandu Valley, (b)

Output  2:  Social  and  environmental  support  provided  in  Melamchi  Valley. 
This  output  will  include  (a)  Social  development  support  (including  income 
generation),  buffer  zone  development,  and  a  health  and  education  program 
implemented and benefiting inhabitants; and (b) resettlement action plan, public

attained.  This output will include a project management unit (PMU) established 
with  effective  decision-making  mechanisms,  as  well  as  a  market-driven 
performance management system, remuneration system, and standard operating 
procedures in place.  

The subproject 2 outputs will be same as those for the current project: 

Output 1: Institutional reforms achieved and efficiently operated. This output 
will include (a) performance targets under lease and license agreement achieved, 
(b) water tariff adjusted in accordance with cost recovery principles, and (c) water 
levy paid from Kathmandu Valley inhabitants to Melamchi Valley inhabitants. 
Output  2:  Water  distribution  and wastewater  system  improved. This output 
will include (a) capital works for bulk distribution system and distribution network 
improvement  undertaken  and  potable  water  supplied  8  hours  per  day,  (b) 
additional  raw  water  source  provides  15  MLD,  and  (c)  wastewater  facilities 
rehabilitated. 
Output 3: Social and environmental support provided in Kathmandu Valley. 
This  output  will  include hygiene  education  and promotion  program,  support  to  a 
low-income  customer  support  unit,  and  environmental  management  plan 
materialized.

Rebidding  process  and  the  new  contract.  After  the  termination  of  the  previous

B. 

Economic and Financial 

21. 
Economic  analysis.  The  estimated  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  the  overall 
project  including the  additional financing  is  18.92%;  the  net  present  value  is  $225.62 million.10 
The  economic  internal  rate  of return  is  higher than  the  economic  opportunity  cost  of capital of 
12%, indicating a sufficient economic return. The results from a sensitivity analysis, which range 
from  17.47%  to  18.92%,  are  satisfactory  against  downside  risks,  including  a  10%  increase  in 
capital  expenditure,  a  10%  increase  in  operating  costs,  a  10%  decrease  in  benefits,  and  a  1-
year delay in project completion.  
 
22. 
Financial  analysis.  The estimated financial internal rate of return of the overall project 
including the additional financing is 7.93%; the net present value is $1.6 million.11 The financial 
internal rate  of return  is slightly  higher  than the weighted  average  cost  of capital,  estimated  at 
7.90%,  indicating  an  adequate  financial  return.  The  sensitivity  analysis  reveals  that  financial 
viability of the project is most vulnerable to decreases in revenues, and efforts will be made by 
KUKL  to  rationalize  tariffs  and  enhance  revenues.  The  future  profitability  of  KUKL  will  be 
evaluated  once  the  water  utility  provides  accurate  financial  projections,  which  are  a 
disbursement condition for the Kathmandu Valley Wastewater Management Project (footnote 7). 
Tariff levels were increased in July 2013 by more than 80% and are expected to increase further 
when water becomes available from the Melamchi tunnel. The government also agreed in July 
2013 to shoulder KUKL’s tax burden through a grant to the utility. With support from the ongoing 
loans  (footnotes  5  and  7),  KUKL  will  continually  work  to  make  operational  and  financial 
improvements, including significant reductions in  nonrevenue water. These elements are likely 
to improve financial performance soon after the completion of the MWSP.

has been updated since 2008, does not indicate that any additional risks or mitigating measures 
will  be  required. 12  Detailed  accounting  and  auditing  arrangements  are  given  in  the  project 
administration manual. 

 
Poverty and Social 

D. 

A poverty and social analysis has been completed, and the additional financing project is 
24. 
classified  as  no  gender  elements.13 While  the  additional  financing  has  limited  impact  on  the 
social and gender aspects of the people in the Kathmandu Valley, the downstream water supply 
and wastewater projects (footnote 7) prioritize connecting all poor households and households 
headed by women to the water supply and sewerage network in the Kathmandu Valley. Under 
these projects, the government and KUKL have committed to reform current water supply and 
sewerage connection policies to facilitate individual connections to the poor, socially excluded, 
and households headed by women. Connection fees will be reduced for poor households under 
these projects. A social uplift program (SUP) under the MWSP is being implemented to promote 
widespread,  ongoing,  and  meaningful  participation  of  key  stakeholders. 14 These  projects  will 
complement  KUKL's  ongoing  efforts  to  strengthen  its  pro-poor  and gender-inclusive  sanitation 
services.   

 
Safeguards 

E.

resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement 
(2009).15 The  additional  financing  for  the  MWSP  will  not  change  the  safeguards  requirements 
from the original project as there will be no additional scope or civil  works to be implemented. 
The PMU submits regular social safeguard monitoring reports to ADB, and these are reviewed 
and  disclosed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009).  No  significant 
social  safeguard  implementation  issues  have  arisen,  and  the  PMU  is  capable  of  effectively 
implementing all safeguards. SUP activities will be continued for Melamchi Valley in line with the 
original  scope  and  will  cover  five  areas:  buffer  zone  development,  health,  education,  income 
generation, and community development. The inputs of the safeguard and social development 
support  consultant  will  be  continued  to  (i)  build  capacity  of  the  Melamchi  Valley  Development 
Committee,  MWSDB,  and  relevant  stakeholders;  (ii)  support  the  development  committee  in
